SOCIETE DES NATIONSReduction des depenses nationales pour les armements,Note du Secretaire General.Les documents suivants sont communiques, a litre cTinformation au Conseil, aux Membres de la Societe et aux Membres de la Commission provisoire de la reduction des armements :I. Lettre en date du 8 mars 1921, envoyee par le Secretaire General, conformement a la resolution du Conseil en date du 25 fevrier 1921.II. Reponse des Gouvernements de :a) Afrique du Sud : 6) Belgique,c) Bresil,d) Grande-Bretagne, dl) Canada,e) Chine,/) Danemark,g) Finlande,h) France,i) Guatemala, /) Inde,k) Italie, /) Japon, m) Pays-Bas, n) Norvege,o) Etat serbe-croate-slovene.IGeneve, le 8 mars 1921.Monsieur le Ministre,Le Conseil me charge de transmettre aux Gouvernements de tous les Etats Membres de la Societe, le voeu ci-joint, adopte a la majorite de 1'Assemblee, au sujet de la limitation des depenses militaires, navales et aeriennes pendant les deux annees fiscales qui suivront le prochain exercice budgetaire de chaque Etat Membre.Le Conseil m'a en outre charge de prier les Gouvernements des Etats Mem-bres de la Societe de vouloir bien me faire connaitre avant le ler mai quelle suite ils se proposent de donner a ce vceu.Je saisis cette occasion de prier Votre Excellence de vouloir bien agreer les assurances de ma haute consideration.Le Secretaire General:(Signe) ERIC DRUMMOND. LEAGUE OF NATIONSReduction of National Expenditure on Armaments.Note by the Secretary-General.The following documents are circulated for the information of the Council, the Members of the League and of the Temporary Commission on the reduc-tion of armaments :I. Letter of the Secretary-General of March 8th, 1921, written in accord-ance with the resolution of the Council of February 25th, 1921 ;II. Replies from the Governments of :(a) South Africa,(b) Belgium,(c) Brazil,(d) Great Britain, d1) Canada,(e) China,(/) Denmark,(g) Finland,(h) France,(i) Guatemala, (/) India,(k) Italy, (/) Japan,(m) The Netherlands, (n) Norway,(o) Serb-Croat-Slovene State.IGeneva, March M, 1921.Sir,I am instructed by the Council of the League of Nations to forward to the Governments of all Members of the League the enclosed recommendation adopted by a majority vote of the Assembly with regard to the limitation of military, naval and air expenditure during the two financial years following the next budget of each Member.The Council further instructed me to request the Governments of the Members of the League to be so good as to inform me before May 1st whether they propose to give effect to this recommendation.I have the honour to be, Sir,Your obedient servant,(Signed) ERIC DRUMMOND, Secretary- General.S. el. VOEUadopte parLASSEMBLfiE DE LA SOCIETE DES NATIONSle 14 decembre 1920.En attendant le plein effet des mesures concernant la reduction des arme-ments prevue a 1'article 8 dn Pacte, 1'Assemblee emet le vceu que le Conseil sou-mette a 1'examen des Gouvernements la proposition d'accepter 1'engagement de ne pas depasser, pendant les deux annees fiscales qui suivront le prochain exer-cice, le chiffre global des depenses militaires, navales et aeriennes prevues pour cet exercice. Sous reserve qu'il sera tenu compte :1) De toute contribution d'effectifs, de materiel dc guerre, d'argent recom-mandee par la Societe des Nations pour F execution des obligations prevues a 1'articlc 16 du Pacte ou dans les traites enregistres par la Societe ;2) Dc toute situation exceptionnelle qui sera signalee au Conseil de la Societe des Nations, conformement a 1'esprit cles paragraplies 2 et 6 de 1'article 8 du Pacte.II[Traduclion.]REPONSE DU GOUVERNEMENT SUD-africa in. Bureau du Premier Ministre.Cape-Town, le 20 avril 1920.Monsieur,J'ai 1'honneur de vous accuser reception de votre lettre du 8 mars, N0 21/31/27, transmettant la recommandation de F Assembler de la Societe des Nations, qui demande aux Gouvernements de s'engager a ne pas depasser pour les exercices 1922-23 et 1923-24 le montant global des depenses prevues au budget de 1921-22 pour tous les services militaires, navals et aeriens.Mon Gouvernement est en pleine sympathie avec 1'esprit qui a dicte a FAs-semblee cette recommandation d'ordre pratique, en vue d'appliquer Farticle 8 du Pacte ; mais il me charge d.'informer le Conseil de la Societe qu'il existe certaines conditions exceptionnelles, pour employer les termes de la seconde reserve exprimee dans votre lettre, qui, a 1'heure actuelle, ne permettent pas dc determiner jusqu'a quel point il lui sera possible d'adopter les recomniandations de TAssemblee, tout au moins dans un avenir rapproche.1. L'Union de 1'Afrique du Sud n'a en effet jamais possede de force perma-permanente navale, militaire ou aerienne. Elle n'a pas eu, jusqu'a present, le temps de donner son plein developpement a son armee de citoyens, etantdonne que For-ganisation prevue par le Parlement de FUnion en 1912, n'a jamais pu etre realisee, a cause de Finterruption due a la grande guerre et a la periode d'inaction totale qui Fa suivie.2. Avant la guerre :a) Le Gouvernement Imperial maintenait des effectifs considerables dans le pays, pour la defense de FUnion. RECOMMENDATIONadopted by theASSEMBLY OF THE LEAGUE OF NATIONS, December 14th, 1920.Pending the full execution of the measures for the reduction of armament; recommended by Article 8 of the Covenant, the Assembly recommends to the Council to submit for the consideration of the Governments the acceptance of an undertaking not to exceed, for the first two financial years following the net financial year, the sum total of expenditure on the military, naval and air ser-vices provided for in the latter budget, subject, however, to account being taken of the following reservations :(1) Any contributions of troops, war material and money recommended by the League of Nations with a view to the fulfilment of obligations imposed by Article 16 of the Covenant or by Treaties registered by the League.(2) Exceptional conditions notified as such to the Council of the League of Nations in accordance with the spirit of paragraphs 2 and 6 of Article 8 of the Covenant.REPLY OF THE SOUTH AFRICAN GOVERNMENT. Prime Ministers Office.Cape Town, 20//i April, 1921.Sin,I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of March 8th, No. 21 /31 /27, conveying the recommendation of the Assembly of the League of Nations that Governments should undertake, for the years 1922-23 and 1923-24, not to exceed the sum total of expenditure on the military, naval and air ser-vices provided for in the Budget for 1921-22.While my Government is in cordial agreement with the aim of the Assembly, in thus making a practical suggestion to carry out Article 8 of the Covenant, they desire me to notify the Council of the League, in terms of the second reser-vation contained in your letter, of the following " exceptional conditions " which make it at present uncertain to what extent they will be able to adopt the recom-mendations in the immediate future :(1) The Union has never possessed a standing naval, military or air force. It has not yet had time to develop its citizen force, the organisation devised for that purpose by the Union Parliament in 1912 having never been brought into effective being owing to the interruption caused by the Great War and a period of total inactivity since the cessation of that war.(2) Before the Great War :-(a) The Imperial Government maintained considerable forces stationed in the Union for defence purposes, b) 11 n'cxistait aucune force aerienne imperiale ou locale dans rAfriquedu Sud.c) Cetait le Gouvernement Imperial, et non le Gouvernement de 1'Unionqui se chargeait de la defense navale de 1'Afrique du Sud, ports, eaux territoriales ou routes cle commerce maritimes.3. Actuellement, le Gouvernement Imperial a retire en fait la totalite (les troupes formant la garnison reguliere stationnee sur les territoires de 1'Union avant la guerre, et il est probable qu'il incombera a lTJuion de prendre a son compte les charges militaires assumees anterieurement par le Gouvernement Imperial pour les besoins cle la defense locale.La part cle 1'Union dans la defense navale de 1'Afrique clu Sud devra etre egalement determinee d'accord avec le Gouvernement Imperial. Toutes ces me-sures seront discutees au cours de la Conference qui doit se tenir a Londres a breve echeance. II semble done qu'il serait premature de faire une declaration a l'heure actuelle, au sujet des depenses de 1'Union en matiere de defense mili-taire, navale ou aerienne.Je desire enfin insister d'une facjon generate sur la situation et les condi-tions geographiques de 1'Union et attirer sur ce point 1'attention du Conseil :1) Le territoire de rUnion s'etend sur 473.000 milles carres, et renferme une l)opulation indigene qui, actuellement, se degage a peine de 1'etat barbare et dont le nombre depasse celui de la population europeenne dans une proportion cle 4 a 1.2) II existe, meme sur les frontieres, des territoires de 1'Union qui, quoique situes dans sa sphere d'influence economique et politique, depassent la popu-lation europeenne dans une proportion bien plus considerable. Etant donne que 1'Union est de beaucoup le plus important des pays civilises de 1'Afrique centrale et de 1'Afrique du Sud, 1'evolution pacifique et progressive des autres Etats et des autres territoires, ainsi que les conditions de bien-etre et de bon gouvernement des races indigenes de 1'Afrique ou des dependances africaines de 1'hemisphere sud sont des questions d"importance vitale pour 1'Union.3) Le statut international de 1'Union, et, partant, les charges qui lui incom-bent pour la defense du territoire etant de fraiche date, 1'Union n'a encore pu, comme d'autres Etats qui ont eu 1'occasion depuis des annees, de prendre a cette fin les mesures appropriees, preparer un programme de defense.De plus, ayant accepte le mandat pour le territoire sud-africa in, elle se trouve avoir a defendre une frontiere maritime bien plus longue, et elle a en outre a se charger de la responsabilite de maintenir l'ordre et la paix sur un territoire con-siderable, renfermant un grand nombre d'indigenes a peine sortis de 1'etat bar-bare.Etant donnees les conditions exceptionnelles dont il est fait mention dans la premiere partie de ce memorandum, ainsi que la situation geographique et les circonstances mentionnees plus haut, le Gouvernement de 1'Union, tout en don-nant son assentiment de principe a la politique de la Societe des Nations, ne croit pas pouvoir, a 1'heure actuelle, donner les assurances definitives que com-porte la recommandation de 1'Assemblee.II est a peine besom d'aj outer que le programme militaire et naval envisage par l'Union vise exclusivement la defense de 1'Afrique du Sud et le maintien de l'ordre et de la paix a 1'interieur, et qu'il ne serait d'aucune valeur pratique dans le cas d'une agression sur territoire etranger ou d'operation militaire en dehors de 1'Afrique du Sud. Ce programme est done tout a fait conforme a 1'ideal pacifique que la Societe des Nations a tant a coeur.Veuillez agreer, etc.....(Siyne) SMUTS,Premier Ministre.Au Secretaire general de la Societe des Nations. Geneve. Finally, I desire to emphasise, for the consideration of the Council, " the geographical situation and circumstances " generally of the Union :(1) The territory of the Union covers 473,000 square miles and contains a native population in the process of emerging from barbarism, which outnumbers the European population by 4 to 1.(2) There are, however, in South Africa, territories surrounding the Union, but within the Union's economic and political sphere, wherein the native popu-lation outnumbers the European population in far greater proportion. Seeing that the Union is far and away the strongest civilised State in Central and Southern Africa, the peaceful and orderly development of other States and territories, and the welfare and good government of the indigenous native races of Africa and the African Continent in the Southern hemisphere, are matter of vital concern to the Union.(3) Only recently has the Union acquired international status, with its concomitant obligations in the way of national defence, and while other States have for years past made adequate provision for this purpose, the Union has had as yet no opportunity to lay down a basis for future guidance.Besides, by accepting the Mandate for south-West African territory, she has not only largely increased her seaboard, but has rendered herself liable for the peace, order and defence of a large territory, containing large numbers of natives, hardly developed from the stage of barbarism.Owing to the exceptional conditions mentioned in the first part of this memo-randum, and the geographical situation and circumstances enumerated herein, the Union Government, while they are in general agreement with the policy of the League of Nations, do not feel at present justified in giving the definite assurances which the recommendation of the Assembly suggests.It is needless to add that the military and naval organisation contemplated for the Union has reference entirely to the defence of South Africa and the main-tenance of internal order and peace, and would be useless from the point of view of foreign aggression or operations to be conducted outside of South Africa. It is therefore in complete conformity with the peaceful ideals which the League has at heart.I have the honour to be, etc.(Signed) SMUTS.Prime Minister.The Secretary-General, League of Nations, Geneva.(b) There was no air force, Imperial or Union, in South Africa.(c) The Imperial, and not the Union, Government assumed responsi-bility for naval defence of South African ports, waters and trade sea-routes.(3) The circumstances of the present day are that the Imperial Govern-ment has withdrawn practically the whole of the Regular Garrison stationed in the Union before the war, and it is likely that the Union will have to assume the military obligations which before the Great War were assumed by the Imperial Government for purposes of local defence. The Union's share in the naval defence of South Africa has also still to be determined in consultation with the Imperial Government. These matters will be discussed at a Conference which it is pro-posed to hold in London at an early date ; and any declarations as to the expen-diture of the Union on military, naval and air defence in the immediate future would therefore be premature at present. B.Bruxelles, le 21 avril 1921.Monsieur le Secretaire General,Comme suite a votre communication en date du 8 mars dernier 21/31/27, j'ai rhonneur de vous faire connaitrc que 1c Gouvernement beige se conformera au voeu adoptc par 1'Assemblee de Geneve, tendant a voir les Gouvernements s'engager a nc pas depasser, pendant les deux annees fiscalcs qui suivront le pro-chain exercicc, lc chiffre global des depenses militaires, navales et aeriennes prevues pour cet exercice, sous reserve qu'il sera tenu compte :1) De toute contribution d'effectifs, de materiel de guerre, d'argent, recom-mandee par la Societe des Nations pour 1'execution des obligations prevues a 1'article 16 du Pacte ou dans les traites enregistres par la Societe.2) De toute situation exceptionnelle qui sera signalee au Conseil de la Societe des Nations, conformement a 1'esprit des paragraphes 2 et 6 de 1'article 8 du Pacte.Veuillez agreer, etc.(Signe) HENRI JASPAR.A 1'Honorable Sir Eric Drummond,Secretaire General de la Societe des Nations, Geneve.REPONSE DU GOUVERNEMENT BRESILIEN.Legation des Etats-Unis du Bresil.Berne, le 29 avril 1921..Monsieur le Secretaire General,La Legation des Etats-Unis du Bresil en Suisse, sur un ordre de son Gou-vernement, s'empresse de porter a la connaissance du Secretariat General de la Societe des Nations que le Gouvernement bresilien yient de donner des instruc-tioiis a son representant au Conseil de la Societe au sujet du vceu emis par la premiere Assemblee generale de Geneve, relatif a la limitation des depenses iriili-taires, navales et aeriennes pendant les prochaines annees fiscales.En priant le Secretariat General de la Societe des Nations de vouloir bien accuser reception de cette communication, la Legation cles Etats-Unis du Bresil saisit volontiers cette occasion pour lui renouveler, avec ses remerciements anti-cipes, les assurances de sa haute consideration.Au Secretariat general de la Societe des Nations. B.Brussels, April 21s/, 1921.Sir,With reference to your letter of 21/31/27 of March 8th last, I have the honour to inform you that the Belgian Government will conform to the recom-mendation adopted by the Geneva Assembly to the effect that the Governments should undertake not to exceed, in the two financial years following the next budget, the total sum of military, naval and air expenditure allowed for in that budget with the reservation of:(1) Any forces, war material or money supplied at the instance of the League of Nations for the execution of the engagements undertaken in virtue of Article 16 of the Covenant or of the Treaties registered by the League.(2) Any exceptional circumstances of which the Council of the League of Nations is informed, in accordance with the spirit of paragraphs 2 and 6 of Article 8 of the Covenant.I have the honour to be, etc.(Signed) FIENRI JASPAR.The Hon. Sir Eric Drummond,Secretary-General of the League of Nations, Geneva.REPLY OF THE BRAZILIAN GOVERNMENT.[Translation.]Legation of the United States of Brazil.Berne, April 29th, 1921.Sir,Under instructions from its Government, the Legation of the United States of Brazil in Switzerland has the honour to inform the Secretariat-General of the League of Nations that the Brazilian Government has just transmitted to its representative on the Council of the League its instructions with reference to the recommendation of the first Geneva Assembly regarding the limitation of military, naval and air expenditure during the coming financial years.The Legation of the United States of Brazil will be much obliged if the Secretariat-General of the League of Nations would kindly acknowledge receipt of this communication and begs to tender its thanks in anticipation.- To the Secretariat-General of the League of Nations, ,, Geneva^Ministry of Foreign Affairs. I., le 2 juin 1921.Monsieur le Secretaire General,Le Gouvernement de Sa Majeste a examine avec attention votre lettre du 8 mars, a laquelle etait joint le voeu, adopte le 14 decembre 1921, a la major-rite des voix, par 1'Assemblee de la Societe des Nations, concernant la reduction des depenses navales, militaires et aeriennes de chaque Membre de la Societe, pendant les deux annees fiscales qui suivront le prochain exercice.En reponse a votre lettre, j'ai rhonneur de vous informer que la politique du Gouvernement de Sa Majeste est entierement conforme a 1'esprit de la recom-mandation adoptee le 14 decembre par 1'Assemblee de la Societe. Le Gouverne-ment de Sa Majeste a deja tres considerablement reduit ses depenses navales, militaires et aeriennes, et envisage la possibilite de realiser de nouvelles eco-nomies au cours des deux annees qui vont suivre. Cette politique doit cependant etre sujette aux reserves mentionnees dans la recommandation.Le Gouvernement de Sa Majeste tient, en meme temps, a signaler que si les recommandations de FAssemblee ne sont pas adoptees par d'autres Puissances, sa politique devra faire 1'objet d'un nouvel examen.Veuillez agreer, etc....(Signe) A. W. 1, June 2nd, 1921.Sir, \ ' *His Majcsty's Government have under careful consideration your letter of March 8th enclosing the recommendation adopted on December 14th, 1920, by a majority vote of the Assembly of the League Of Nations with regard to the limitation of naval, military and air expenditure during the two financial years following the next budget of each Member.In reply,! have to inform you that the policy of His Majesty's Government is entirely in harmony with the spirit of the recommendation adopted on De-december 14th by the Assembly of the League. His Majesty's Government have already effected very substantial reductions in their naval, military and air expenditure, and look forward to the possibility of further economies in the next two years. These, however, must be subject to the reservations mentioned in the recommendation.At the same time, His Majesty's Government desire to point out that, if the recommendations of the Assembly are not adopted by other Powers,'their policy must be liable to reconsideration.I am Sir,Your obedient Servant,(Signed) A. J. BALFOUR.The Hon. Sir Eric Drummond, K.C.M.G.; C.B., League of Nations, Geneva.REPLY OF THE CANADIAN GOVERNMENT.Department of External Affairs. E. T.Ottawa, May, 27 th 1921.Sir,I am instructed to reply to your letter of March 8th to the Prime Minister of Canada concerning the recommendation adopted on December 14th, 1920, 14 decembre 1920, & la majorite des voix, par la premiere Assemblee de la Societe des Nations, au sujet de la limitation des depenses militaires, navales et aeriennes pendant les deux annees fiscales qui suivront le prochain exercice financier dc chacun des Membres de la Societe.Le Gouvernement canadien envisage avec sympathie toutes mesures des-tinees a amener une reduction generate des armements, et sa politique actuelle est en parfaite harmonie avec 1'esprit de ladite recommandation. Je dois aj outer que les depenses affectees a la defense de ce Dominion ont toujours 6te relative-ment tres peu elevees; elles paraissent meme etre aujourd'hui, par tete d'habitations-tant, plus faibles que celles d'aucune autre nation. Considerant 1'augmentation actuelle du cout de toutes choses, le Gouvernement a effectue de serieuses reduc-tions sur 1'ensemble des depenses militaires, navales et aeriennes; il espere vive-ment pouvoir en operer davantage pendant les deux annees qui suivront, en tenant compte, toutefois, des reserves mentionnees dans la recommandation de 1'Assem-blee.Veuillez agreer, etc.(Signe) JOSEPH POPE.Sous-Secretaire cCEtat aux Affaires Etrangeres, Canada.L'HonorableSir Eric Drummond K.C.M.G., C.B. REPLY OF THE CHINESE GOVERNMENT.League of Nations Service of the Chinese Republic.49, Portland Place, London, W. 1., May llth, 1921.Sir,Pursuant to instructions from my Government, I have the honour to inform you that my Government, being in entire accord with the spirit underlying the recommendation of the Assembly, adopted on December 14th, 1920, for the li-mitation of expenditure on the Military, Naval and Air Services, has decided to give effect thereto.I have the honour to be, etc.(Signed) V. K. WELLINGTON KOO.To the Hon. Sir Eric Drummond, Secretary-Generalof the League of Nations, Geneva.by a majority vote of the First Assembly of the League of Nations with regard to the limitation of military, naval and air expenditure during the two financial years following the next budget of each Member of the League.The Canadian Government looks with favour on any measures calculated to bring to pass a general reduction of armaments, and its present policy is in entire accord with the spirit of the recommendation above referred to. I am instructed to say also that the expenditures for defence of this Dominion have always been relatively very low and are to day believed to be the lowest per capita of any nation. The Government has effected substantial reduction in the aggregate on military, naval and air expenditures, having regard to the increased costs now prevailing, and in the next two years looks forward earnestly to the possibility of further reductions, though these must be subject to the reser-vations embodied in the Assembly's recommendation.I have the honour to be, etc.,(Signed) JOSEPH POPE.Under-Secretary of Stale for External Affairs, Canada.The Hon.Sir Eric Drummond, K.C.M.G., C.B., The Secretary-General of the League of Nations, Geneva REPONSE DU GOUVERNEMENT DANOIS.MlNISTERE DES AFFAIRES ETRANGERES.Journal N0 11 B. 31.(Recu le 29 avril 1921.)Monsieur le Secretaire General, :Par une lettre du 8 mars dernier, n0 21/31/27, vous avez bien voulu me faire parvenir un exemplaire du voeu adopte a la majorite de FAssemblee, le 14 decembre 1920, au sujet de la limitation des depenses militaires, navales et aeriennes pendant les deux anhees iiscales qui suivront le prochain exercice budgetaire de chaque Etat Membre.En meme temps, vous avez bien voulu me faire savoir que le Gonseil vous a charge' de prier les Gouverncments des Etats Membres tie la Sbciete de vous faire connaitre, avant le ler mai, quelle suite ils se proposent de donner a ce voeu.En reponse, je m'empresse de vous faire connaitre ce qui suit:En Danemark, ime commission instituee en vertu de la loi n0 55 du 12 fevrier 1919, a ete chargee d'elaborer un plan pour rorganisation future de'1'armee et de la marine danoises. Cette commission au sein de laquelle sont representes tous les partis politiques principaux du Paiiement danois, a deja etudie un projet de reorganisation militaire.Or, comme aucun parti n'a presente de'projet comportant une augmentation des depenses militaires, et que le Gouverncment lui-meme n'a pas 1'intention de presenter de projet en ce sens, il est invraisemblable qu'il se produise en Dane-mark, pendant les deux annees fiscales qui suivront le prochain exercice budge-taire, une augmentation des depenses militaires, navales -et1 aeriennes.Je vous prie de vouloir bien, si possible, me faire savoir les points de vue des autres Membres de la Societe au sujet de la question dorit il s'agit.Veuillez agreer, etc.(Siyne) HARALD SCAVENIUS.Sir Eric Drummond, Secretaire general de la Societe des Nations, -Geneve. (Received April 29th, 1921.)Sir,In a letter dated March 8th last, N0 21/31/27, you were good enough to send me a copy of the recommendation adopted by a majority of the Assembly on December 14th, 1920, with reference to the limitation of military, naval and air expenditure during the two financial years following the next budgetary period of each State Member of the League.At the same time you were good enough to inform me that the Council had instructed you to request the Governments of the States Members of the League to inform you before May 1st of the steps which they proposed to take with a view to giving effect to this recommendation.In reply I beg to communicate to you the following facts : -In Denmark a Commission, set up by virtue of the law No. 55 of February 12th, 1919, lias been instructed to draw up a plan for the future organisation of the Danish Army and Navy. This Commission, upon which all the principal political parties of the Danish Parliament are represented, has already drawn up a scheme of military re-organisation.As no party has submitted a scheme involving an increase in military expen-diture, and as the Government itself has no intention of submitting a scheme involving such an increase, it is improbable that during the two financial years following the next budgetary period there will be an increase in the military, naval and air expenditure of Denmark.I beg you to be good enough to inform me if possible of the points of view of the other Members of the League with regard to this question.I have the honour to be, etc.(Signed) HARALD SCAVENIUS.Sir Eric Drummond, Secretary-Generalof the League of Nations, Geneva.Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Journal No. 11.B.31. REPONSE DU GOUVERNEMENT FINLAND A IS.Legation de Finlande,Ref. N0 367. 22, rue de la Paix,\ . Paris, le 26 avril 1921.Monsieur le Secretaire General,A la suite de votre obligeante lettre a Monsieur le Ministre des Affaires Etrangeres de Finlande, en date du 8 mars ecoule, invitant le Gouvernement fin-landais a examiner, conformement a la resolution de Geneve du 14 decembre 1920, s'il pouvait prendre 1'engagement de ne pas depasser, pendant les deux annees fiscales qui suivront le prochain exercice, le chiffre global des depenses militaires, navales et aeriennes prevues pour cet exercice, mon Gouvernement, sans prendre parti sur la valeur de principe de la resolution precitee, m'a charge de vous communiquer ce qui suit :Le credit destine a des buts militaires a atteint, en 1919, 22% des depenses total de 1'Etat, en 1920,18%, en 1921,15%. S'il est vrai que les depenses total de 1'Etat ont successivement augmente, le pourcentage du credit destine aux de-penses militaires accuse une baisse constante.La Finlande, vu sa situation geographique exposee et ses cotes etendues, a besoin d'une marine, qui actuellement fait presque totalement defaut. D'autre part, les fortifications necessaires a la frontiereEst ont seulement ete commencees. Les casernes sont insuffisantes, Tarmement et 1'equipement des troupes defect-tueux et surannes ; une reorganisation s'imposait, dont les travaux sont actuel-lement en cours. The funds allocated for the construction of warships have been limited to what is necessary to continue and complete the. construction of certain ships actually on the stocks, the building of which began several years ago.Thus the Budget scheme as presented does not provide for the construction of new ships, nor for the acquisition of armaments, such as guns, rifles, torpedoes and mines. Up to the present, the sums necessary for purchases of this nature were Charged against either the Ordinary or Extraordinary Budget. No Extraor-dinary Budget has been presented for the last two years, nor will there be one this year.Having regard to the reduced value of money, the Budget proposed for ' next year is really lower than those voted before the war, and is less than that which would normally be considered necessary for the maintenance of even the present forces. As a result of the scrapping of material and the reduction in numbers of personnel, the efficiency of the Fleet has been considerably impaired in comparison with the state of things existing a few years ago.
